Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: How much does your life weigh?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Excuse me?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Oh... No. Um, no thank you.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Who the fuck are you?

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: What did I... do? What could I have done differently here?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: This is not an assessment of your productivity. It's important not to personalize this.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Oh, I'm sure it's going be really helpful.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Right...

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Take the day. Put together your personal things. Talk to your co- workers. Tomorrow, go out and get some exercise. Go for a jog. Give yourself routines and pretty soon you'll find your legs.

Speaker: steve
Dialogue: Wait, how do I get in touch with you?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Don't worry. We'll be in touch soon. This is just the beginning.

Speaker: checkout girl
Dialogue: Do you have your Hilton Honors Card with you?

Speaker: checkout girl
Dialogue: Oh my God... Do you like, live, at the Hilton?

Speaker: airport clerk
Dialogue: Pleasure to see you again, Mr. Bingham.

Speaker: airport clerk
Dialogue: Pleasure to see you again, Mr. Bingham.

Speaker: kevin
Dialogue: Ryan Bingham's office.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: You have me in a Dodge Stratus in Kansas City.

Speaker: kevin
Dialogue: They are completely out of all full sized sedans...

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Did you?...

Speaker: kevin
Dialogue: Yes, I reminded them of your remarkable #1 Gold Club status and years in the program. They are moving mountains to see you in a Sebring.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Fair enough. Any other messages?

Speaker: kevin
Dialogue: Your sister Kara called. Needs to speak urgently about your sister's wedding. I told her you were midair and not even I knew your final destination.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Well done.

Speaker: kevin
Dialogue: And you got an invitation to speak at GoalQuest in Vegas.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: GoalQuest twenty?

Speaker: kevin
Dialogue: It's got a hologram. They're calling it Dos Equis. That's some pretty major Tony Robbins shit there.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Talk about burying the lead.  I'll check in when...

Speaker: kevin
Dialogue: Hold on, I have Craig Gregory for you...

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I... ah, fuck...

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: How's the road warrior?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Twenty minutes from boarding into a world of bliss.

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: Great numbers out of Phoenix. You know Big Auto is going to drop another 10K this month.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: No kidding?

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: Yeah, Christmas came early. Wish I could have you in five places at once. I need you back in Omaha by the end of the week.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I thought you needed me everywhere.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I don't know why you ever bring me in. Wherever I go, the money follows. Let me plant seeds, they'll grow to Oaks.

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: I'm thinking of planting seeds right now.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: What are we talking about here?

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: You'll see.  Today, I took my first crap in two weeks. Hallelujah.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: That's me, hanging up on you.

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: Good. I love that sound.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Hello?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Hey Kara.

Speaker: kara
Dialogue: How are you holding up?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Just fine. You? The kids?

Speaker: kara
Dialogue: Missy's outstanding. Matthew made varsity. How's the road?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Couldn't be better.

Speaker: kara
Dialogue: That's good. So, Ryan?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Yeah?

Speaker: kara
Dialogue: I didn't even want to have to ask you for this, because I know how you are about... doing things for others...

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: kara
Dialogue: We've been sending people these kits so they can print out photos of Julie and Jim on cardboard, and take photos of them in interesting places kind of like that gnome in the French movie.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: kara
Dialogue: Because it's Julie's wedding... and she thinks it's fun. Does it matter why?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: How is Julie?

Speaker: kara
Dialogue: Would you call her? She thinks you've turned to butter - Disappeared. You're awfully isolated, the way you live.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Isolated? I'm surrounded.

Speaker: kara
Dialogue: Your assistant told me you're going to be in Vegas.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Did he?

Speaker: kara
Dialogue: Can you get a photo of the cut-out in front of the Luxor Pyramid?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: That place is a shit hole. No one stays there.

Speaker: kara
Dialogue: Jesus, Ryan, I'm not asking you to check in. Can you just take a stupid photo?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I'm going to try my best.

Speaker: kara
Dialogue: Well, thank you for trying your best.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: You're satisfied with Maestro?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Yeah, I am.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: They're stingy with their miles. I like Hertz.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Hertz keeps its vehicles too long. If a car's over twenty-thousand miles, I won't drive it.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Maestro doesn't instant check out. I like to park and go.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Hertz doesn't guarantee Navigation.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Funny, you don't seem like a girl who needs directions.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I hate asking for directions. That's why I get a Nav.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: The new outfit, Colonial, isn't bad.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Is that a joke?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Their kiosk placement is a joke.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Never have available upgrades.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: It's basically a fleet of shit boxes - Don't know how they're still in business.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I'm Ryan.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Alex.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: So are you going to join me?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Maplewood Card? How dare you bring that into this palace.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Hilton offers equal value and better food - But the Maplewood gives out warm cookies at check in.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: They got you with the cookies?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I'm a sucker for simulated hospitality.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: There's actually an industry term for that. It's a mixture of faux and homey. It's faumey.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Oh my God. I've heard about these, but never seen one in person. Is this a...?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Concierge Key. Yeah.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I love the weight.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Graphite. I was pretty excited the day that puppy came in.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I'll say. I put up pretty pedestrian numbers. Sixty thou a year, domestic.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: That's not bad.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Don't patronize me. What's your total?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: That's a personal question.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Oh please...

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I hardly know you.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Show some hubris. Impress me.  I bet it's huge.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: You have no idea.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Come on...  ... this big?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Let's just say I've got a number in mind and I haven't hit it yet.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: This is pretty fucking sexy.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I hope it doesn't cheapen our relationship.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: We're two people who get turned on by elite status. We may have to settle for cheap.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: There's nothing cheap about loyalty.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I really have to start throwing these out.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: We can always use that room with the ice machine.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Good call on the towel rack.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Thanks. I liked how you burritoed me in the sofa cushions.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I was improvising.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Too bad we didn't make it to the closet.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: We got to do this again.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I'm in Newark on the 12th, Madesto on the 13th, Oklahoma City on the 15th.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Any Southwest? I'm swinging through Albuquerque the week of the 16th?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: No, but I'll be in Florida by the 20th.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Miami?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Ft. Lauderdale.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: That's nothing.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Forty minutes.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I should probably go back to my room so I can wake up in my bed.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I think that's the lady like thing to do.

Speaker: nosey neighbor
Dialogue: Ryan?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Hi...

Speaker: nosey neighbor
Dialogue: Feels like it's been months, busy man. We missed you at our Summer party.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Yeah, sorry I couldn't be there.

Speaker: nosey neighbor
Dialogue: We've been trying to get a vote on the new landscaping. Can I e-mail you the plans...? We'd love to get a final tally.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: It's fine. Really. I'll go with the majority.

Speaker: nosey neighbor
Dialogue: Sometimes I forget that you even live here. You could probably save money and move into a hotel.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I looked into it, but the IRS requires a permanent address for employment. Otherwise, they classify you as a vagrant.

Speaker: nosey neighbor
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: woman's voice
Dialogue: Hey neighbor.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Hey yourself.

Speaker: dianne
Dialogue: I signed for this while you were gone.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Thanks. Hope it wasn't a bother.

Speaker: dianne
Dialogue: They seem happy.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: It's my sister. She's getting married. Haven't met the guy yet.

Speaker: dianne
Dialogue: Lots of luck.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I know, right?

Speaker: dianne
Dialogue: It's good to see you. Feels like a while this time.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Hey, you want to come over tonight?

Speaker: dianne
Dialogue: Actually, I kind of started seeing somebody.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Oh, that's... that's great.

Speaker: dianne
Dialogue: Yeah, we're having drinks tonight if you want to come over.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: That's okay... I' think I'll settle in.

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: Just thrilled to have everyone under one roof. Welcome home boys.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: If there's one word I want to leave you with today, it's this...

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I don't understand. I'm fired?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Hearing the words "You've been let go" is never easy. Change is always scary. But consider the following -  Anybody who ever built an empire, or changed the world, sat where you are now. And it's because they sat there that they were able to do it.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: That's my fucking line.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Well, what happens now?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: This is the first step of a process that will end with you in a new job that fulfills you.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Yeah, but, how does it work?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: I want you to take that packet in front of you.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: I understand.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Have a good day, Mr. Laskin and good luck with your future.

Speaker: ned
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Give it up for Ned.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Tell me you're not taking this seriously.

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: Yeah, that's why we brought the entire company in from the road - Because we're not taking this seriously.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: It doesn't make any sense. It's...  ... completely impersonal.

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: Who am I even talking to?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: There's a methodology to what I do. A reason why it works.

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: Ryan, Coke and IBM have been doing it for years. Just like anything, there's a few months of transition, but everyone settles in.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Who are you taking off the road?

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: You don't get it. You're grounded, Ryan. Everyone is. It's done.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Okay, what we do here is brutal and leaves people devastated, but there's a dignity to the way I do it.

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: Stabbing people in the chest instead of the back?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: You wanted to see me?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Yeah, why don't you come in.

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: Great job in there, Nat.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Thank you. How's everyone taking it?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Look, I appreciate your... zeal. And you have some good ideas. But you know nothing of the realities of my job. Sure, you can set up an iChat... but you don't know how people think.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Actually, I minored in psychology.

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: Nice.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Okay kiddo, fire me.

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: Ryan, stop it.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: She's going to be doing this on a regular basis. You don't want to know if she can fire somebody?

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: She just fired Ned.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: My dog could fire Ned.  Fire me.

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: Ryan.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: It's okay, I got this.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Who the hell are you?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: My name is Miss Keener and I'm here today to discuss your future.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: My future? I don't know you. The only person who can fire me is Craig Gregory.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Mr. Gregory hired me to handle this for him.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Handle what? Handle me? Mr. Gregory hired me and he's the only one who can fire me. I'm going to talk to him.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Mr. Bingham...

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: You can't follow me... You're on a computer screen. Remember?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Ryan...

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Try again. Fire me.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: I just did.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Actually, you didn't. Now, fire me.

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: Stop it, Ryan.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Mr. Bingham, I'm here today to inform you that your position is no longer available.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I'm fired?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Yes, you're fired.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Never say fired.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: You've been let go.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: This is a mythical situation. How could I possibly know why?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: You never know why. Why doesn't matter.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: It's important not to focus on the "why" and rather to spend your energy thinking about your future.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I'm going to spend my energy on suing you if you don't give me a reason that you're firing me.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Mr. Bingham, the reason is not important.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Oh, so you're firing me without grounds.  Now, I really have a lawsuit.

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: Ryan, I think we know what you're trying to say...

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Don't take this personally, Mr. Bingham.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Personally?  This is the most personal situation you will ever enter. So before you try to revolutionize my business, I'd like to know that you actually know my business.

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: Hell-of-a-way to welcome her to the team.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Am I the only one who sees that by automating our own business, we're making ourselves irrelevant.

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: No... We're making you irrelevant.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I'm not... I'm not a dinosaur.

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: I want you to show her the ropes.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: What do I know about what happens around here? Have Ferguson do it.

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: I'm not talking about here.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: Hey, you seem pretty confident that this girl doesn't know what she's doing...

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Excuse me. I just don't think a MySpace page qualifies you to rewire an entire company.

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: Great. Well, here's your chance. Show her the magic. Take her through the paces.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I'm not a fucking tour guide.

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: This is the boat.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Yes. Alone.

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: Ryan, we're ringing the bell. Rounding everybody up. If you want to stay out there a little longer, you can. But you're not going to be on your own.  Let me know.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Huh.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: I really like my luggage.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: That's exactly what it is. Luggage.  You know how much time you lose by checking in?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: I don't know, maybe five minutes waiting for...

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Thirty five minutes per flight. I travel two hundred seventy days a year. That makes one hundred fifty seven hours... That's Seven Days.  You ready to throw away a whole week on that?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Bingo. Asians.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: You can't be serious.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Never get behind people travelling with infants. I've never seen a stroller collapse in less than twenty minutes.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: That's racist.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I'm like my mother. I stereotype. It's faster.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Are you upset at your laptop?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: No. Why?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Fats Domino had a lighter touch.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: I type with purpose.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: What are you working on so furiously?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: I'm building a work flow of firing techniques. Questions & responses. Actions & reactions. A script that works kind of like a tributary, taking you through the steps of firing someone.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Who is it for?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Theoretically, you could put it in the hands of anybody and they could be downsizing immediately. All they have to do is follow the steps.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Natalie, what is it, you think we do here?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: We prepare the newly unemployed for the emotional and physical hurdles of job hunting while... Minimizing potential legal blowback?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: That's what we're selling. But it's not what we're doing.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Okay, what are we doing?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Our job is to make limbo tolerable - To ferry wounded souls across the river of dread and humiliation to the point at which hope's bright shore is dimly visible...  And then to stop the boat, shove'em in the water, and make them swim while we row back to the palace of their banishment to present the employers with our bills.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: That was really impressive. You rehearse that?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I got to grab this. I'll meet you at the rental lot.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Hey, I was hoping I'd hear from you.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I'm in Hotlanta. I need a rib joint recommend bad.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Fat Matt's. Bring a bib.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: You haven't called.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: You know, I didn't know what was appropriate...

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Ryan, I'm not some waitress you banged in a snow storm. The word "Appropriate" has no place in our collective vocabulary. I'm the woman you don't have to worry about.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: This sounds like a trick.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Next time you're worried about manners - Don't. If you want to call - Call. Just think of me as yourself... only with a vagina.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: When am I going to see you?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I'm out of Hartsfield, into IAD, then a connection at ORD into SDF.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Oh... sorry.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Tell me about it.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: How long is your layover in O'Hare? They've got multiples into SDF... Think you could push?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I can push.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Ryan Bingham, from CTC.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: All you have to do today is watch and listen. When I talk about the strategy packet. You hand them one of these...

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: You ever find it strange that termination comes with a packet.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Everything important in life comes with a packet.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Thank you for coming by. As you're probably well aware, this is a tough economic climate and your company is not immune.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: While I wish I was here with better news, the reason you and I are meeting is this is your final week of employment here.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: This is not a time to look for blame. Your position simply no longer exists.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I understand why you are saying these things.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Fill out the skill set work sheet... Use the hopes and dreams diagram... And the tree of aspirations.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: The answers are all in there.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: The answers are all in there.  ... are-all-in-there.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: And what do you suggest I tell them?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Perhaps you're underestimating the positive effect your career transition may have on your children.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Positive effect?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Well, tests have shown that children under moderate trauma have a tendency to apply themselves academically as a method of coping.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Go fuck yourself. That's what my kids'll think.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Your children's admiration is important to you?

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Yeah. It was.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Well, I doubt they ever admired you, Bob.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Hey asshole, aren't you here to console me?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I'm not a shrink, Bob. I'm a wake up call. You know why kids love athletes?

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Because they screw lingerie models.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: No, that's why we love athletes. Kids love them because they follow their dreams.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Yeah, well I can't dunk.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: But you can cook.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: What are you talking about?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Your resume says you minored in French Culinary Arts. Most students work the frier at KFC. You bussed tables at Il Picatorre to support yourself. Then you got out of college and started working here.  How much did they first pay you to give up on your dreams?

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Twenty seven thousand a year.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: At what point were you going to stop and go back to what made you happy?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Do you believe in fate, Bob?

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Fate?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Yeah. You know, the mysterious ways in which we wind up doing the things we were meant to do.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: I met my wife at a gas station.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Exactly. Well, I think fate is telling you to do something, Bob.

Speaker: business woman
Dialogue: I've been waiting ten minutes. He just waltzes in and gets to cut in line.

Speaker: desk clerk
Dialogue: We reserve priority assistance for our Hilton Honors members.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: You should look into it - The promotions are great...

Speaker: business woman
Dialogue: Fuck off.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: You okay?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Yeah. Fine.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Hungry, much?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Our expense account allots for forty dollars each on dinner. I plan on grabbing every mile I can.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Okay, you got to fill me in on this mile business. What's that all about? Are you talking like frequent flier miles?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Your really want to know?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: I'm dying to know.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I don't spend a nickel, if I can help it, unless it somehow profits my mileage account. I'm not talking hotel rooms and rental cars either, but internet services, cell phone, music downloads, teleflorists. The works. I shop them according to the miles they pay and I pit them against each other for the most value.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: So, what are you saving up for? Hawaii? South of France?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: No, it's not like that... The miles are the goal.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: That's it? You're saving to save?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Let's just say I've got a number in mind and haven't hit it yet.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Wow. Seems a little abstract. What's your target?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I'd rather not.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: It's a secret target?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: It's ten million miles.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Huh. Isn't ten million just a number?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Pi is just a number.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: I guess we all need a hobby.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I'd be the seventh person to do it. More people have walked on the moon.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Do they give you a parade or something?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Lifetime Exec Platinum status. You get to meet the Chief Pilot, Maynard Finch. And... They put your name on the side of a plane.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Men get such a hard-on from putting their name on stuff... You guys don't grow up - You just need to pee on everything.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Now, who's stereotyping?

Speaker: nancy
Dialogue: Fear of mortality. It's like Yes, you're going to die one day.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: And why do you suppose that's singular to men?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Probably cause you can't have babies.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Thanks for the advice.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Man alive.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Left, left, left, left... one more inch... and stop.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: I don't get it.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: My sister is cooky. She thinks this is charming... Like the gnome thing.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: No, I mean... why would your sister want a fake photo in front of the St. Louis Airport?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: She should be so lucky to visit Lambert Field. The Wright Brothers flew through there...  The domed main terminal was the first of its kind. A precursor to everything from JFK to DeGualle.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Wow. Pretty sweet.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Why she wants dozens of reminders of all the places she hasn't been is beyond me.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Well, I'm sure she's going to be crushed for having missed this airport.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Look - Before Lindbergh could cross the Atlantic, he took off from one of those runways... Ever wondered why they call it the Spirit of St. Louis?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Sometimes, they just need to vent.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Please, for the love of God, can I fire the next one?

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: I'm here to be fired, right?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: We're here to talk about your future.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: You don't have to sugar coat it. I get the drill. What are they offering?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Inside the packet you'll find a clearly worked out severance package.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Give me the bullet points.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Three months pay. Six months medical. A full year of placement services through our company, CTC.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Placement services? How generous.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Commonly, it takes one month of searching for every ten thousand dollars you expect to earn in salary.

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: So I could be looking for a while.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Not necessarily...

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Oh, don't sweat it. I'm pretty confident about my plans.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Oh yeah?

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: Yeah. Can you tell me? Is high tide in the morning or the evening?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: I don't know. Why?

Speaker: karen
Dialogue: There's this beautiful bridge by my apartment. I need to figure out what time to jump off it.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: People say these things all the time. It comes with the trade.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: They do?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Sure. People are always saying crazy stuff. They get worked up.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: She was so calm.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I think that's a good sign.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: So they don't actually ever do it?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: No... it's just talk.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: How do you know? Do you follow up?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I mean, no, nothing good can come of that, but I don't think you should worry about it.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: I'll be back soon. Not really sure how long this whole exercise is supposed to last. He's fine... It's hard for these guys to accept change, you know.  I... I'm not even going to answer that... No, I can't even think of him that way... He's old.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Okay. This is where it gets a little difficult, but stay with me. You have a new backpack... but this time, I want you to fill it with people. Start with casual acquaintances, people around the office, friends of friends and work your way to the people you trust with your most intimate secrets. Now move into family members - cousins, aunts, and uncles. Get your sisters and your brothers and you parents. Get them all in that backpack. And finally your husband or wife or boyfriend or girlfriend. Get them in their too.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Never...?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Is that so bizarre?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Yes. Yes it is.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I don't see the value.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Sell me marriage.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: I... Uh... How how about love?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Pff...

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Okay. Stability?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: How many stabile marriages do you know?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Someone to talk to, spend your life with?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I'm surrounded by people to talk to. I doubt that will change.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: How about just not dying alone?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Starting when I was twelve, we moved each one of my grandparents into a nursing facility. My parents went the same way.  Make no mistake. We all die alone.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Oh fuck.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Brian left me.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Oh, hey... I...

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Hi. Alex this is Natalie. Natalie, this is my... friend, Alex.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I should give you both a moment.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: No, it's fine. I'm fine. Just stupid emotions.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Maybe a drink?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Now we're talking.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: He broke up with you over text message?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: That's kind of like firing people over the internet.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: What a weasely prick.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Yeah, but what does that make me? Someone who falls for a prick?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: We all fall for them. Pricks are spontaneous, unpredictable, and fun. And then we're surprised when they turn out to be pricks.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: I followed him to Omaha.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: You did?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: I had a job waiting for me in San Fran, when he got an offer from ConAgra. He told me we could start a life together. So I followed him.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: To Nebraska.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: I look in the mirror and I just see compromise... I'm supposed to do something.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: You'll do plenty.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: I just can't... I thought I'd be engaged by now.  No offense.

Speaker: alex ryan
Dialogue: It's alright. None taken.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: When I was sixteen, I thought by twenty three, I would be married, maybe have a kid... Corner office by day, entertaining at night. I was supposed to be driving a Grand Cherokee by now.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Life can underwhelm you that way.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Now I have my sights on twenty nine, because thirty is just way too... apocalyptic. I mean, where did you think you'd be by...

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: It doesn't work that way.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: At a certain point, you stop with the deadlines.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: They can be a little counterproductive.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: I don't want to say anything that's... anti-feminist. I mean, I really appreciate everything your generation did for me.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: It was our pleasure.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Well done.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: But sometimes it feels like no matter how much success I have, it all won't matter until I find the right guy.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: You really thought this guy was the one.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Yeah, I guess. I don't know. I could have made it work. He just really fit the bill.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: The bill?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: My type. You know, white collar. College grad. Loves dogs. Likes funny movies. Six foot one. Brown hair. Kind eyes. Works in finance but is Outdoorsy, you know, on the weekends.  How about you?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I'm not sure if...

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: I meant Alex...

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Huh, let me think for a sec.  Well, by the time you're thirty four, all the physical requirements are pretty much out the window. I mean you secretly prey he'll be taller than you.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Wow. That was depressing.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Tried it. We're no picnic ourselves.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: I don't mind being married to my career, and I don't expect it to hold me in bed as I fall asleep.  I just don't want to settle.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: You're young. Right now you see settling as some sort of failure.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: It is. By definition.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Don't worry, by the time someone is right for you, it won't feel like settling... And the only person left to judge you will be the twenty four year old girl with a target on your back.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: So, what's the plan for this evening?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: What...? Oh, is it illicit?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: No...

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: It's nothing like that.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: We are in Miami.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: ... We were going to hit that party for the tech conference in the hotel.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: I didn't know you could just attend those...

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Well, I mean...

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: You're going to crash it?

Speaker: ryan alex
Dialogue: I mean, I don't know if... More money than they know These guy put on a quite a what to do with... party...

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: No, I get it. I'm in!

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Jennifer Chu?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Oh shit!

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: It's going to be fine.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: You okay there?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Oh yeah... This was a great idea.  You are so pretty. You're exactly what I want to look like in fifteen years.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Thank you, Natalie.

Speaker: conference leader
Dialogue: How's everyone doing out there?!

Speaker: conference leader
Dialogue: I'm going to need you to all put your hands together for a very special guest - YOUNG... M... C!

Speaker: young mc
Dialogue: THIS HERE'S A TALE FOR ALL THE FELLAS... TRY TO DO WHAT THOSE LADIES TELL US... GET SHOT DOWN CAUSE YOU'RE OVERZEALOUS... PLAY HARD TO GET, FEMALES GET JEALOUS...

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Think she'll be okay?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Look...

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Back home, I don't get to act the way I do with you.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: That's why I don't have a "back home".

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I know. You're so cool. "Mr. Empty Back Pack".

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: You know about the back pack?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I googled you.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: You did?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: It's what us modern girls do when we have a crush.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Did it bother you?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Well, that depends. Is the bag empty because you hate people or just the baggage they bring along?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I don't hate people. I'm not exactly a hermit.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: You just don't want to be tied down? The whole responsibility thing.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I don't think it's even that... I... First time I ever flew, I was sixteen.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: You're not going to answer? You're just going to tell me a story?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: It was January and I had just gotten my driver's license. The lakes were frozen over, so we piled into my car and hit the ice to do donuts. When, out of nowhere, I hit a soft spot and the hood of my car tilted up and I was sinking backwards into the water.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Jesus...

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I literally started to drown. Within a few seconds, I black out. Then, I wake up in the sky. I'm in a helicopter, laying on a stretcher. This guy in a uniform is telling me I was minutes away from dying.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Oh my God.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Right?  My parents had taught me we lived in the best place on Earth, but now I could see the world was really just one place and comparing didn't make much sense. And I remember thinking - Don't tell me this isn't an age of miracles. Don't tell me we can't be everywhere at once.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I don't know what originally sparked the back pack. I probably needed to be alone. Recently, I've been thinking that maybe I needed to empty the bag before I knew what to put back in.

Speaker: software dude
Dialogue: Hey... I think we're out of gas.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Hey, you're up...

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Got to fly stand-by and make a meeting in Milwaukee.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Oh... Okay.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Oh, no. I made you feel cheap.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Yeah, all right... Just leave the money on the dresser.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I'll text you later so we can swap schedules.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I can't remember the last time I enjoyed spending time with someone as much as you.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Neither can I.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Last night got a little out of hand. I said things... I don't remember everything I said. I just didn't want you to think...

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Just relax. It was nice to see you cut loose. So, did you wake him up or slip out?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: This morning... Your new friend. Did you wake him for an awkward good bye or just slip out so he could feel like a whore.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: I... just left.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Protocol is always tricky.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: I didn't know what was right.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Sometimes there really is no right thing to do.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: What happened to Alex?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Had to skip town early to make a meeting.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: That's too bad. Where does she live?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Chicago.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: You thinking of going to see her?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I don't know. We just don't have that kind of relationship.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: What kind of relationship do you have?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: It's, you know. Casual.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Sounds pretty special.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: It works for us.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Think there's any future there?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Never thought about it. What's going on here?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Really never thought about it?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: How can you not think about these things? How does it not even cross your mind that you might want to have a future with somebody?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: It's simple, you know that moment when you look into someone's eyes and you feel them looking right into your soul, and the whole world goes quiet for a second.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Right. Well, I don't.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: You're an asshole.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Oh come on, I'm just dicking around. I need your help...

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Don't you think it's worth giving her a chance?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: A chance to what?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: A chance at something real?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Natalie, your definition of "real" is going to evolve as you get older...

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Would you stop condescending for one second? Or is that one of the principles of your bullshit philosophy?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Bullshit philosophy?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: The isolation? The traveling? Is that supposed to be charming?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: No, it's simply a life choice.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: It's a cocoon of self-banishment.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Wow. Big words.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Screw you.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Well, screw you too.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: You've set up a way of life that basically makes it impossible for you to make any human connections. Now, somehow, this woman runs the gauntlet of your ridiculous "life choice" and comes out the other end with a smile - Just so you can call her casual. Jesus. I need to grow up? You're a twelve year old.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I don't have a gauntlet of...

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: ... Fuck!

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: These Detroit guys can be tough. They've been getting hammered. Don't get distracted. Stick to the simple stuff. Get the packet in their hands and get them out the door.

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: Welcome to Detroit.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: What's going on here?

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: I've been getting those great numbers over the last few days. Thought we should nut up and give this a try.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: We could use a little more time.

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: Gotta leave the nest at some point.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: This is a real company, Craig. We're here to do some damage.

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: I know. Good thing we brought our best. So let's stop screwing around, alright?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Just give me a minute to prepare and get my things together.

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: I was thinking Natalie takes this one.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: She's hardly ready for this.

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: I've been watching her. She's great.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: This is a whole other animal...

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: I mean, she created it. Natalie, you not up for it?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: I'm... I'm game.

Speaker: craig gregory
Dialogue: Atta girl.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Just remember, don't apologize. Don't tell them how hard this is for you. Today is one of the worst days they will ever have. What we feel doesn't even compare.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Got it.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Just keep it professional. You're going to do fine.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Hello, Mr. Samuels. My name is Natalie Keener.

Speaker: samuels
Dialogue: What's going on here?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: I wish I was here with better news, however your position here at Deckers is no longer available.

Speaker: samuels
Dialogue: What are you talking about?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: You've been let go.

Speaker: samuels
Dialogue: What, just like that? I can't believe... Who are you?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: My name is Miss Keener. I am here to tell you about your options...

Speaker: samuels
Dialogue: I work here for seventeen years and they send some fourth grader in here to can me? What the fuck is this?!

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: It's perfectly normal to be upset. However, the sooner you can tell yourself that there are greater opportunities waiting for you...

Speaker: samuels
Dialogue: Greater opportunities? I'm fifty- seven-fucking years old!

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Anybody who ever built an empire, or changed the world, sat where you are now. And it's because they sat there that they were able to do it.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: You did good.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: No, I'm alright.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: We're being pulled off the road.  We're going home.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: For good?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: That's what it looks like.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: I'm sorry about what I said about Alex. I was out of line.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: It's alright. I understand.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: I mean, who am I to be dolling out relationship advice?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: It's fine.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: You going to be okay?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: In Omaha?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Oh, I don't know.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: It's better than you'd think.

Speaker: natalie
Dialogue: Ryan, where are you going?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Grabbing another flight... Something I need to take care of. I'll see you in, uh... at home.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I have to admit, when you asked me to meet you in Vegas... I thought we'd gamble, make out in a heart shaped jacuzzi, maybe see one of those weird French Canadian circus shows.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: There'll be plenty of time for all that.  One more foot to the left.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: How do you feel about the wedding?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I'm fine, I guess.  Okay great... walk away.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: They're a cute couple.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Think so?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Yeah, they'll make cute kids. If they're lucky, maybe look a little like you.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: How do you like Wisconsin in February?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Who doesn't?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Northern Wisconsin.  What are you doing this weekend?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: What? I haven't even...

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I can't.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I couldn't.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I'm being serious.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: You want me to be your date?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Well... Yeah.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: To a wedding... Jesus, Ryan. Your sister's wedding?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: It's not like I know her that well.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: I'm just not sure if it's appropriate for me to...

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Look. You know. I'm not the wedding type. But for the first time in my life... I don't want to be that guy, alone with his drink. I want a dancing partner. I want a plus one. And if you can stomach it, I'd like it to be you.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Yeah, I can't believe I... Yeah, I'm in. When is it?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I feel like we should kiss or something.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Then kiss me.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Are you available?

Speaker: kara
Dialogue: Ryan?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Kara...

Speaker: kara
Dialogue: Well, hello.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: kara
Dialogue: Ryan has told me nothing about you.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Kara, what are you doing at a hotel?

Speaker: kara
Dialogue: Fuck, I was hoping I wouldn't have to... Yeah, uh, Frank and I are trying out a trial separation.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: You're not staying at the house?

Speaker: kara
Dialogue: There was an extra room on hold here, so I just took it for the weekend.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Oh, okay.

Speaker: kara
Dialogue: Yup. So, you guys are dating?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Um...

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: It's not exactly...

Speaker: kara
Dialogue: Hey, don't worry about it. We're all getting a little old to be calling someone girlfriend... I remember when mom used to call Jack her boyfriend. It drove me up the wall. Boyfriends are for kids...  And I'm just a divorcee!

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: So, the rehearsal dinner?

Speaker: kara
Dialogue: Yeah, I'll see you two there.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: There's a packet.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: What in life is worth doing that doesn't have a packet.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Um, I love you?

Speaker: julie
Dialogue: Oh my God, Ryan!

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: The basket was very lovely.

Speaker: julie
Dialogue: Tammy wrapped all of them.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Me? You're the one getting married.

Speaker: julie
Dialogue: I know, right? You haven't even seen my ring.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I brought those photos you were asking for...

Speaker: julie
Dialogue: Oh great! They go over there.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: There were quite a few already up there. Almost couldn't find room.

Speaker: julie
Dialogue: I know, isn't it great how everyone chipped in?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: What gave you the idea to do something so...

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: ... Substantial?

Speaker: julie
Dialogue: Well, Jim has a lot of our nest egg invested in this real estate venture right now. So when we went over our finances, a honeymoon just didn't seem affordable this second... So I thought... Hey, just because we can't travel doesn't mean we can't have pictures.

Speaker: alex
Dialogue: It was a great idea.

Speaker: julie
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: It's sixty acres up against the foothills. I subdivided the old Lazy W Ranch and took a nice slice for myself.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Sounds nice.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Homes will go in the high fours.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Must be a nice development.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: It's a community, not a development. The concept is turn-key everything. You buy a maintenance contract with the home. We'll whack your weeds, we'll even change the light bulb. Furniture? You buy your own or choose a package. Seamless traditionalism, yet all the perks.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Nice.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: We all need a place to call our own. This is America. This is what we were promised.

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: That's a nice touch.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: That bit at the end about promise... I like it.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: So, you still renting that one- bedroom?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: I gave it up.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: You own now?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: But you're looking?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: Not really. No.

Speaker: tammy
Dialogue: Can you believe it's tomorrow?! How are you going to sleep?

Speaker: julie
Dialogue: I don't know!

Speaker: tammy
Dialogue: You want some Xanax?

Speaker: ryan

Dialogue: Yeah.

Dialogue: Oh.

Dialogue: Yup. Sleep tight.

Dialogue: Yeah, of course...

Dialogue: I haven't been to bat. I haven't been in the dugout.

Dialogue: Hey, it might have helped you.

Dialogue: Come on, Ryan. You haven't been around much. Fuck, you basically don't exist to us. I know you want to be there for her... Well here it is. This is your chance.

Dialogue: Ryan?

Dialogue: Oh, hey Jim.

Dialogue: I was just laying there last night in bed and I couldn't sleep. I was thinking about the wedding and the ceremony and all. Us buying a house and moving in together. Having a kid... Having another kid...  ... Thanksgiving, Christmas, spring break, football games, all of a sudden they're out of school, getting jobs, getting married, And then, you know... I'm a grandparent. I'm retired. Before you know it - I'm dead... and I just kept thinking... "What's the point?"

Dialogue: The point?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Yeah, I mean, what am I starting here?

Speaker: ryan
Dialogue: It's marriage... it's the most beautiful thing on Earth... you know, what everyone aspires to...

Dialogue: That's true...

Dialogue: Jim, I'm not going to lie. Marriage can be a pain in the ass. And you're kind of right - All of this is just stuff on the way to your eventual demise.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: No... I guess not.
